title: TU81: How Good Boundaries Actually Bring Us Closer, with Guest Juliane Taylor Shore
description:
How Good Boundaries Actually Bring Us Closer
Interpersonal co-regulation requires boundary setting.Â Most of us havenâ€™t been lucky enough to learn to be good at boundary setting naturally, by good examples, so we have to literally be taught how to do this important skill.Â Well today we are in luck!Â Jello will be your friend.Â ğŸ™‚

Therapist UncensoredÂ co-hosts Ann Kelley and Sue Marriott join the founder ofÂ IPNB Psychotherapy of Austin, Dr. Juliane Taylor Shore, in a discussion on interpersonal neurobiology and how it relates to boundaries.Â Weâ€™ll explore the three types of boundaries, how to co-create boundaries and how to stay regulated using internal mechanisms. After this podcast, you may very well be on your way towards building your own â€œJelloÂ wallâ€ and better co-regulating yourself when youâ€™re overwhelmed!

0:00-25:00

Some background on Juliane Taylor Shore:Â Founder of IPNBÂ Psychotherapy of AustinÂ with interests in interpersonal neurobiology, neuroscience, philosophy, biology and physics.

How are boundaries defined and what sort of connotations come with boundaries? How can the connection between boundaries and interpersonal neurobiology actually bring people closer?

The Three TypesÂ ofÂ Boundaries

External, BehavioralÂ Boundary:Â â€œI donâ€™t want to talk to you when you raise your voice at me.â€ Or â€œIâ€™d love to see you but I canâ€™t right now.â€Â The concept of having to say â€œnoâ€.

Psychological Boundary:Â separation between people, difference between true self and parts of selfÂ (â€œairâ€ between people, your truth and my truth are allowed to be different)Â â€œJelloÂ Wallâ€

ContainingÂ Boundary:Â (individually deeming whatâ€™s okay leading up to healthy shame)Â Boundary that stops you from acting out.

Co-creating boundariesÂ between two people is a great way toÂ negotiate disagreementsÂ and find a middle ground.

â€œFucked up people will try to tell you otherwise, but boundaries have nothing to do with whether you love someone or not. They are not punishments, judgments or betrayals. Theyâ€™re a purely peaceable thing. The basic principles you identify for yourself that define the behaviors you will tolerate from others, as well as the responses you will have to those behaviors. Boundaries teach people how to treat you and they teach you how to respect yourself.â€ â€“ Cheryl Strayed (Author ofÂ Wild:Â From Lost to Found on the Pacific Crest Trail)

â€œJelloÂ wallâ€:Â Stop and slow down all the input coming towards you so you can ask, â€œIs this true or not true?â€ and â€œIf it is, is this about me or not about me?â€Â This allows you to view the world around you without getting hurt.Â Allows you space to reflect and be in your own system.

The differences between theÂ logicalÂ left brainÂ andÂ abstractÂ right brainÂ influenceÂ how they connect neural networks.Â HealthyÂ shame is important to not beat oneâ€™s self up over establishing boundaries.

Using young ones andÂ animalsÂ to teachÂ your inner protector parts to have aÂ betterÂ containing boundary,Â relieving trauma by talking to your young selfÂ (you at four, sixteen, etc.)Â rather than beating your presentÂ self up.

25:00-50:00

Exploring the connection between attachment and interpersonal neurobiology.

The anticipation of threat before setting a boundary andÂ connecting to something after getting overwhelmed so that itâ€™s part of your life narrative and not something that keeps popping up.

The individual nervous system isnâ€™t meant to survive being alone after trauma but we need co-regulatory nervous systems AND you can be your own co-regulatory system.

You can start by building up your relationship with yourself and learning to trustÂ your internal voices, neural networks or other people.

Examples working through the three types of boundaries; Co-creating a boundary with a spouse over lack of communication. Turning down a panicked client when youâ€™re totally booked.Â Having uncomfortable physical contactÂ with an older family member when saying goodbye.
